ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live lecture, also recorded
Basically a lecture that was synchronous and recorded
This class was in between a virtual lecture / seminar. Lots of dicussion, but organized around powerpoint slides / the professor teaching us the material.
Attended almost every lecture live in-person. Used Canvas notes and media library a lot to study
Since the class had about 40 people, there was a mix between seminar discussion and virtual lecturing. It was all live, with the option of watching recordings.
Live lectures and was recorded
None
live lecture, was recorded

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned a lot about options, SPACs, closed end funds, M&A, and how all of these are consistent/inconsistent with market efficiency. Huge focus on arbitrage opportunities in markets.
Prof was a hedge fund manager, so he talks a lot about interesting deals and types of arbitrage he's seen or even done. Course used to be called hedge funds if that gives you some insight
Thinking more critically about various current events and types of "arbitrage". Also learned some standard bond and option pricing

I learned so much in this class. I learned all about shorting strategies, futures / forwards markets, merger arbitrage, CDS, risky debt valuation, options valuation, activist hedge funds, + more all through the lenses of arbitrage/ hedge fund strategy.
Learned a lot about how markets work in the real world.

Understanding of a variety of topics in the hedge fund space, mainly focused on credit and equity. We discussed merger (risk) arbitrage, convertible arbitrage, option pricing and put-call parity, yield curve bootstrapping, credit default swaps and basis risk, futures and forwards, activism, share classes, and much more.
I learned about the role of investment vehicles (particularly pooled ones, ex. Hedge funds) and about the overall investment and financial landscape.
Learned about hedge funds, arbitrage, bonds, options, and activist investors. Great class!

I learned an immense amount regarding the hedge fund industry and the ways in which investors and traders might go about finding and exploiting market anomalies. The class is pretty applicable, although the mathematical details are kept broad. The class spans most of the topics from standard corporate finance, with a spin to focus on arbitrage and market dynamics.
This course provided me with an in depth understanding of the financial world of hedge funds.
Market inefficiencies

Market analysis and quantitative skills 
Also knowledge of current events
Great insight on market inefficiencies.

I learned a lot about Financial instruments and how they interact. I have more to think about now whenever reading Financial News. It was interesting to learn how investment funds capitalize on transient mis-pricings in the market and the what the risks are of these "limited arbitrage" trades.
Financial markets, hedge fund strategies, market inefficiencies

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Super practical course relative to other econ classes at Yale. If you're considering being a trader after college you should definitely take this. Sometimes tangents in lectures make it a little hard to pay attention, and first few midterms can be tricky, but overall a good course. There are definitely a lot of midterms (4 + a final), so it can feel like you're taking exams a lot. The readings every week weren't super helpful because they were so long and technical and we were never really expected to know them so there wasn't much motivation to do them.

Pascutti is a little disorganized but not so much so in this course compared to his corp. finance course. If you took corporate with him, this will be on the easier side for you since some of the same topics are covered.
Pascutti is super entertaining and open to student feedback.

Strength -- learned a lot and Professor Pascutti is a great lecturer. He is clear and always has great stories to tell. He does a great mix of lecturing, telling stories, and engaging students in examples.

Weakness -- Professor Pascutti is a genius and so has high expectations. The 4 quizzes took a lot of studying.

Strengths: really interesting material, great instructor, frequent and fair assessments

Weaknesses: the lecture notes were often all over the place. needed to watch the lecture recordings to understand them. Prof Pascutti says that he normally doesn't make powerpoints so that might be the explanation.

The pandemic hurt this course because Prof. Pascutti is a great in-person lecturer. He still did a very good job over Zoom, but it is inevitably more difficult to be engaging over a computer, which is one of his greatest strengths as a teacher.
Tests were a bit tricky, but fair! Just wish we had more practice problems/more complex problem set questions to get the hang of concepts before they were tested on exams.

The class was very enjoyable to attend as the professor always brings great stories and commentary on the well-customized material. It also was very effective in getting across the points about market anomalies and how to exploit them (or why it is often difficult to exploit them safely or at all.)

There felt like there were a few too many quizzes/midterms (a total of 4, plus the final exam) so we were always on our toes for another assessment. This could also be seen as a positive, however, so not a huge critique.
Incredible, enthusiastic professor. The material was engaging and was constantly updated based on current market trends and events.

Topics could have been better organized. Also powerpoints and writing things on the board could be helpful. Also the policy of handing in things late and getting your grade lowered Stinks because my computer is super slow.

Strengths-relevant content, engaging discussions
Weaknesses-none
Great class. A little more structure may help with exams, but the loose schedule makes it easy to talk about real world stuff which is way more valuable than following a script

There was a lot of reading that was repetitive and not addressed in the week following. Professor seemed disorganized. For example, we had a midterm on a Monday and then we went over the material on the test for the first time that Wednesday. The grade distribution of that test was huge because of  the pre existing varying levels of experience in the course material. Some students had worked two internships in what we talked about; others had little to no experience. This is the nature of how things go, but the wide range of test scores (lowest being a 10%, highest being a 100%, median was around 50%) was an indicator of the lack of relevant material being taught for this particular midterm.

I liked that the problem sets were Pass/Fail. However, they were not always a good preparation for the tests, and we had a lot of tests. There were 4 quizzes, and I only could finish one of them in time! The Final Exam took the whole 3 hours! The readings had little relation to the class and almost no relation to the tests. I still read them, of course, as they did describe important pieces of research in the space. Overall, it was this over-testing that was the only weakness. You can mitigate that hassle with a CR/D and still learn a lot, or if you have taken a class with the prof. before, you can probably know what to expect and do quite well.

Very interesting material taught by Prof. Pascutti who has extensive experience in the field. Interesting to get his thoughts and views on certain phenomena. He also tailors the course to cover current events (ie SPACs in Fall 2020).  Downside of this is that about midway through the term the structure of the course (which had been very well defined in the beginning) began to fall apart which made understanding exactly what was important/going on challenging at times.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: More consistent recording of lectures would be helpful (sometimes it was forgotten/done halfway through). Also, perhaps utilizing some digital whiteboard thing instead of presenting math on slides would've made it easier to learn.
Lectures were recorded which made studying easier
He was able to keep the class engaged despite being in zoom. In particular, he had a nice mix in class of explaining the material and conversation with students.

This course was better than any other at adapting to Zoom, ironically. We all acknowledged during the first class that it would inevitably be a different experience; I think lowering, or at least erasing, some expectations made the class better.
The mix between discussion and lecture worked well.
The live virtual lectures were great ways to keep us engaged with the material.
Great to watch the recordings as well
The class notes were very helpful
Virtual testing could be improved.
very well done

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would definitely recommend this course to a student interested in finance, but it's not a casual introduction to finance course that you should take if you don't have any background. Definitely assumes you've either worked in finance or taken intro to corporate finance.
Yes, interesting class for people interested in finance in general
Yes, definitely recommend!
Yes, I don't think there's another course that teaches live finance material as this one does

I would recommend this class to those interested in the subject matter. We cover a lot of topics with respect to hedge funds, and we often discuss them in great detail. If you're interested in the class, this is great. Otherwise, it can be painful.
Yes. Prof. Pascutti is very engaging and it is one of relatively few ubdergrad finance courses.

Absolutely! Professor Pascutti is one of my favorite professors of all time. He is smart, compassionate, and really understands his students in a rare way. Fantastic guy, would recommend any course he teaches.
Yes, if you are at all interested in the careers that span several areas of finance, or want to understand market inefficiencies, then this class is worthwhile.
Absolutely. The course was difficult but very rewarding. Do not expect a walk in the park. But, if you put the time in then the reward is incredible.
Yes!
Yeah professor its a great guy and has a lot of knowledge. Been around the field and was really good at what he did.

Consider the Strength/Weakness Response:
Maybe. The Problem Sets were Pass/Fail, but they were not always a good preparation for the tests, of which we had quite a lot. There were 4 quizzes, and I only could finish one of them in time! The Final Exam took the whole 3 hours! The readings had little relation to the class and almost no relation to the tests. I still read them, of course, as they did describe important pieces of research in the space. Overall, it was this over-testing that was the only weakness. You can mitigate that hassle with a CR/D and still learn a lot, or if you have taken a class with the prof. before, you can probably know what to expect and do quite well.
Yes if you have interest in financial markets and more nuanced events that occur within them.
